At the top there is a banner reading "It's Scotland's oil campaign message" (text) accompanied by a simple cartoon oil rig silhouette labeled "\"Oil rig silhouette\" (figure)" and a stylized map marker labeled "\"Map marker\" (figure)", and this section also includes the phrase "Discovery of oil in the North Sea" (text). context: During this time, the discovery of oil in the North Sea and the following "It's Scotland's oil" campaign of the Scottish National Party (SNP) resulted in rising support for Scottish independence, as well as the SNP. The party argued that the revenues from the oil were not benefitting Scotland as much as they should. The combined effect of these events led to Prime Minister Wilson committing his government to some form of devolved legislature in 1974. However, it was not until 1978 that final legislative proposals for a Scottish Assembly were passed by the United Kingdom Parliament.

At the top there is a clear header showing the referendum context with the quoted "Under Scotland Act 1978 an elected assembly" (text) and a symbolic ballot-box illustration quoted as "Ballot box with voting slips" (figure), and this leads into the middle where the requirement is stated with the quoted "majority of electorate and at least 40% threshold" (text) alongside a second illustrative icon quoted as "Simple calendar and checklist graphic" (figure) to represent the referendum date and rules, followed by a short place label quoted as "Planned elected assembly location: Edinburgh" (text) integrated into the narrative, then the result panel that shows the quoted "51.6% voted in favour of assembly" (text) paired with a pie-chart-style illustrative symbol quoted as "Abstract pie chart icon" (figure) and the quoted "32.9% of eligible voters did not vote" (text) to explain why the measure failed, and a concluding caption in the lower area reading the quoted "Referendum failed to establish devolved assembly" (text). The overall style of the image is clean, infographic-like, and informative.
context: Under the terms of the Scotland Act 1978, an elected assembly would be set up in Edinburgh provided that the majority of the Scottish electorate voted for it in a referendum to be held on 1 March 1979 that represented at least 40% of the total electorate. The 1979 Scottish devolution referendum to establish a devolved Scottish Assembly failed. Although the vote was 51.6% in favour of a Scottish Assembly, this figure did not equal the 40% of the total electorate threshold deemed necessary to pass the measure, as 32.9% of the eligible voting population did not, or had been unable to, vote.

At the top there is a small emblematic chart showing public interest represented by a simple icon and the caption "increased demand for a Scottish Parliament" (text), and beside it a symbolic illustration of a crowd labeled "grassroots pressure and campaigning" (figure). In the middle a timeline band contains the quoted label "Conservative Party control of UK government" (text) followed by a stylized meeting-table illustration captioned "representative organisations convening" (figure) and a banner-like text block reading "1989 Scottish Constitutional Convention took place" (text). Below that a document illustration is shown with the caption "published blueprint for devolution in 1995" (figure) and a concise text label "blueprint provided much of the basis for the Parliament" (text). At the bottom a small concluding paragraph is presented as the quoted text "Campaign for a Scottish Assembly began after 1979 referendum defeat" (text). The overall style of the image is clean informational infographic with clear icons, simple illustrations, and readable labeled text.
context: Throughout the 1980s and 1990s, demand for a Scottish Parliament grew, in part because the government of the United Kingdom was controlled by the Conservative Party, while Scotland itself elected relatively few Conservative MPs. In the aftermath of the 1979 referendum defeat, the Campaign for a Scottish Assembly was initiated as a pressure group, leading to the 1989 Scottish Constitutional Convention with various organisations such as Scottish churches, political parties and representatives of industry taking part. Publishing its blueprint for devolution in 1995, the Convention provided much of the basis for the structure of the Parliament.

full_image_caption: The image is an infographic titled "Scottish Parliament Building Overview" (text) focused on "Design, Features, and Opening Facts" (text). At the top, a bold label reads "Since September 2004 the official home" (text) and is accompanied by a simple architectural icon "\"Stylized building silhouette\" (figure)" to indicate the building, then a short phrase states "New Scottish Parliament Building in Holyrood Edinburgh" (text) to identify the location; in the middle a caption notes "Designed by Spanish architect Enric Miralles" (text) alongside another pictogram "\"Abstract architect at work\" (figure)" to represent the designer, and a nearby short line reads "Leaf-shaped buildings and grass-roof merging with parkland" (text) while a third illustration "\"Leaf-like building motif\" (figure)" shows the leaf-shaped form, with an additional line that says "Gabion walls and repeated Raeburn motifs throughout" (text) to describe materials and motifs; at the bottom a ceremonial note reads "Queen Elizabeth II officially opened the new building" (text) together with a small ceremonial icon "\"Ribbon-cutting scene\" (figure)" to signify the opening. The overall style of the image is clean, informative, and museum-quality infographic.
context: Since September 2004, the official home of the Scottish Parliament has been a new Scottish Parliament Building, in the Holyrood area of Edinburgh. The Scottish Parliament building was designed by Spanish architect Enric Miralles in partnership with local Edinburgh Architecture firm RMJM which was led by Design Principal Tony Kettle. Some of the principal features of the complex include leaf-shaped buildings, a grass-roofed branch merging into adjacent parkland and gabion walls formed from the stones of previous buildings. Throughout the building there are many repeated motifs, such as shapes based on Raeburn's Skating Minister. Crow-stepped gables and the upturned boat skylights of the Garden Lobby, complete the unique architecture. Queen Elizabeth II opened the new building on 9 October 2004.

full_image_caption: The image is an infographic titled "Parliament Temporary Homes" (text) focused on "Locations and Events During Construction" (text). At the top there is a banner reading "Parliament Temporary Homes" (text) and a subtitle panel stating "Locations and Events During Construction" (text), and to introduce the subject a simple cartoon building icon labeled "temporary church assembly hall venue" (figure) sits above a brief scene caption that notes the Parliament used the "General Assembly Hall of the Church of Scotland" (text) while its permanent building was being built and that official photographs and television interviews were held in the "courtyard adjoining the Assembly Hall" (text). In the middle a small symbolic courtyard illustration captioned "courtyard photo and interview area" (figure) is connected by arrows to two highlighted relocation panels that state the Parliament was moved to the "former Strathclyde Regional Council debating chamber in Glasgow" (text) in May 2000 and to the "University of Aberdeen for sessions in May 2002" (text), while an explanatory note conveys that the Assembly Hall building was vacated twice to allow for the "meeting of the Church's General Assembly" (text). At the bottom a simple map icon labeled "regional temporary chambers illustrated" (figure) and a final annotation reading "image shows temporary relocation sequence and venues" (text) summarize the timeline and purpose. The overall style of the image is clear, documentary, and infographic-focused.
context: Whilst the permanent building at Holyrood was being constructed, the Parliament's temporary home was the General Assembly Hall of the Church of Scotland on the Royal Mile in Edinburgh. Official photographs and television interviews were held in the courtyard adjoining the Assembly Hall, which is part of the School of Divinity of the University of Edinburgh. This building was vacated twice to allow for the meeting of the Church's General Assembly. In May 2000, the Parliament was temporarily relocated to the former Strathclyde Regional Council debating chamber in Glasgow, and to the University of Aberdeen in May 2002.

context: In addition to the General Assembly Hall, the Parliament also used buildings rented from the City of Edinburgh Council. The former administrative building of Lothian Regional Council on George IV Bridge was used for the MSP's offices. Following the move to Holyrood in 2004 this building was demolished. The former Midlothian County Buildings facing Parliament Square, High Street and George IV Bridge in Edinburgh (originally built as the headquarters of the pre-1975 Midlothian County Council) housed the Parliament's visitors' centre and shop, whilst the main hall was used as the Parliament's principal committee room.

full_image_caption: The image is an infographic titled "Scottish Parliament Presiding Officers" (text) focused on "Election and Roles of the Presiding Officer" (text). At the top there is a header block showing the election process with a labeled sentence reading "the Presiding Officer is elected by one MSP" (text) alongside a simple silhouette cartoon of a voting box and ballots labeled "secret ballot" (figure). In the middle a panel explains current officeholders with a captioned phrase "current speaker Tricia Marwick holds the position" (text) paired with a neutral portrait-style cartoon of a person wearing a sash and speaking at a desk captioned "official presiding figure" (figure). Continuing the central narrative a descriptive line reads "there are 129 MSPs who vote in this secret ballot" (text) and an icon shows three stylized clerks at a table with one seated operating equipment labeled "vote clerk operates electronic voting" (figure). At the bottom functional duties are summarized with two quoted lines reading "chairs chamber proceedings and corporate body" (text) and "assisted by parliamentary clerks interpreting standing orders" (text). The overall style of the image is clean, informational, and infographic-like with simple flat illustrations and clear typographic hierarchy.
context: After each election to the Scottish Parliament, at the beginning of each parliamentary session, Parliament elects one MSP to serve as Presiding Officer, the equivalent of the speaker (currently Tricia Marwick), and two MSPs to serve as deputies (currently Elaine Smith and John Scott). The Presiding Officer and deputies are elected by a secret ballot of the 129 MSPs, which is the only secret ballot conducted in the Scottish Parliament. Principally, the role of the Presiding Officer is to chair chamber proceedings and the Scottish Parliamentary Corporate Body. When chairing meetings of the Parliament, the Presiding Officer and his/her deputies must be politically impartial. During debates, the Presiding Officer (or the deputy) is assisted by the parliamentary clerks, who give advice on how to interpret the standing orders that govern the proceedings of meetings. A vote clerk sits in front of the Presiding Officer and operates the electronic voting equipment and chamber clocks.

At the top there is a simple emblematic silhouette of a speaker at a dais shown as "\"Speaker at Dais\" (figure)" and a concise headline presented as "\"Presiding Officer ensures Parliament works smoothly\" (text)" to communicate who is responsible for effective operation. In the middle a symbolic group of people around a table is depicted as "\"Group Discussing Agenda\" (figure)" with an explanatory blurb reading "\"Parliamentary Bureau sets work agenda and allocates time\" (text)" and a short note explaining membership shown as "\"Parties with five or more seats are represented\" (text) so viewers understand how representation is determined. Below that a symbolic globe-and-flag icon appears as "\"Official International Representation\" (figure)" accompanied by the phrase "\"The Presiding Officer represents Parliament at home and abroad\" (text) reinforcing the external role. The overall style of the image is clean, informative, and infographic-like.
context: As a member of the Scottish Parliamentary Corporate Body, the Presiding Officer is responsible for ensuring that the Parliament functions effectively and has the staff, property and resources it requires to operate. Convening the Parliamentary Bureau, which allocates time and sets the work agenda in the chamber, is another of the roles of the Presiding Officer. Under the Standing Orders of the Parliament the Bureau consists of the Presiding Officer and one representative from each political parties with five or more seats in the Parliament. Amongst the duties of the Bureau are to agree the timetable of business in the chamber, establish the number, remit and membership of parliamentary committees and regulate the passage of legislation (bills) through the Parliament. The Presiding Officer also represents the Scottish Parliament at home and abroad in an official capacity.

At the top there is a header and a simple emblem shown as a small generic chamber icon "\"Chamber silhouette with semicircular seating\" (figure)", and immediately beneath it a concise descriptor "\"Hemicycle arrangement encourages consensus among members\" (text) that states the hemicycle purpose and design. In the middle a labeled diagram is depicted as a clean schematic "\"Simplified semicircle showing party groupings\" (figure)" with an overlaid short fact line "\"131 total seats in the debating chamber\" (text)" and another fact line "\"129 elected MSPs plus 2 Law Officers present\" (text)" that clarifies seat allocation and the presence of the Lord Advocate and Solicitor General. Continuing downward a focused inset shows a small group symbol "\"Front row for First Minister, cabinet and Law Officers\" (figure)" paired with a short note "\"Non-elected Law Officers may attend and speak but cannot vote\" (text)" to explain speaking and voting rights, and an added explanatory tag "\"encourage consensus amongst elected members\" (text)" reinforcing the reason for the seating layout. At the bottom a footer contains a compact reference panel "\"Presiding Officer and clerks sit opposite the chamber\" (text)" summarizing official placement. The overall style of the image is clean, informational, and schematic with minimal decorative detail.
context: The debating chamber of the Scottish Parliament has seating arranged in a hemicycle, which reflects the desire to encourage consensus amongst elected members. There are 131 seats in the debating chamber. Of the total 131 seats, 129 are occupied by the Parliament's elected MSPs and 2 are seats for the Scottish Law Officers  the Lord Advocate and the Solicitor General for Scotland, who are not elected members of the Parliament but are members of the Scottish Government. As such the Law Officers may attend and speak in the plenary meetings of the Parliament but, as they are not elected MSPs, cannot vote. Members are able to sit anywhere in the debating chamber, but typically sit in their party groupings. The First Minister, Scottish cabinet ministers and Law officers sit in the front row, in the middle section of the chamber. The largest party in the Parliament sits in the middle of the semicircle, with opposing parties on either side. The Presiding Officer, parliamentary clerks and officials sit opposite members at the front of the debating chamber.

At the top a stylized ceremonial scene introduces the subject with a simple illustrative object labeled "Parliamentary mace illustration" (figure) and the first explanatory line reading "made from silver and inlaid with gold" (text) to state its composition, and nearby a compact caption reads "gold panned from Scottish rivers" (text) to indicate the gold's origin. context: In front of the Presiding Officers' desk is the parliamentary mace, which is made from silver and inlaid with gold panned from Scottish rivers and inscribed with the words: Wisdom, Compassion, Justice and Integrity. The words There shall be a Scottish Parliament, which are the first words of the Scotland Act, are inscribed around the head of the mace, which has a formal ceremonial role in the meetings of Parliament, reinforcing the authority of the Parliament in its ability to make laws. Presented to the Scottish Parliament by the Queen upon its official opening in July 1999, the mace is displayed in a glass case suspended from the lid. At the beginning of each sitting in the chamber, the lid of the case is rotated so that the mace is above the glass, to symbolise that a full meeting of the Parliament is taking place.

context: Parliament typically sits Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays from early January to late June and from early September to mid December, with two-week recesses in April and October. Plenary meetings in the debating chamber usually take place on Wednesday afternoons from 2 pm to 6 pm and on Thursdays from 9:15 am to 6 pm. Chamber debates and committee meetings are open to the public. Entry is free, but booking in advance is recommended due to limited space. Meetings are broadcast on the Parliament's own channel Holyrood.tv and on the BBC's parliamentary channel BBC Parliament. Proceedings are also recorded in text form, in print and online, in the Official Report, which is the substantially verbatim transcript of parliamentary debates.

context: The first item of business on Wednesdays is usually Time for Reflection, at which a speaker addresses members for up to four minutes, sharing a perspective on issues of faith. This contrasts with the formal style of "Prayers", which is the first item of business in meetings of the House of Commons. Speakers are drawn from across Scotland and are chosen to represent the balance of religious beliefs according to the Scottish census. Invitations to address Parliament in this manner are determined by the Presiding Officer on the advice of the parliamentary bureau. Faith groups can make direct representations to the Presiding Officer to nominate speakers.

At the top there is a labeled header reading "The Presiding Officer decides who speaks" (text) accompanied by a cartoon figure of a gavel-wielding official labeled simply as "Presiding official" (figure), and a nearby short line stating "and the amount of time for which they are allowed to speak" (text) which clarifies timing authority. In the middle a balanced scale icon titled "Different viewpoints and political parties balanced" (figure) sits above a concise explanatory line "Presiding Officer tries to achieve a balance between views" (text) while to its side a podium illustration captioned "Opening speeches given by ministers or party leaders" (figure) is paired with the text "Opening speakers are given between 5 and 20 minutes" (text). At the bottom a speech-bubble graphic captioned "Multilingual speeches possible with agreement" (figure) accompanies the descriptive text "Members may use Scots Gaelic or other languages" (text). The overall style of the image is clear, informative, and infographic-like with clean icons and readable text.
context: The Presiding Officer (or Deputy Presiding Officer) decides who speaks in chamber debates and the amount of time for which they are allowed to speak. Normally, the Presiding Officer tries to achieve a balance between different viewpoints and political parties when selecting members to speak. Typically, ministers or party leaders open debates, with opening speakers given between 5 and 20 minutes, and succeeding speakers allocated less time. The Presiding Officer can reduce speaking time if a large number of members wish to participate in the debate. Debate is more informal than in some parliamentary systems. Members may call each other directly by name, rather than by constituency or cabinet position, and hand clapping is allowed. Speeches to the chamber are normally delivered in English, but members may use Scots, Gaelic, or any other language with the agreement of the Presiding Officer. The Scottish Parliament has conducted debates in the Gaelic language.

full_image_caption: The image is an infographic titled "Decision Time at Parliament" (text) focused on "how MSPs vote using electronic consoles" (text). At the top there is a bold header reading "Decision Time at Parliament" (text) and a subheading beneath that states "how MSPs vote using electronic consoles" (text), and this section also includes a small stylized photo-like figure of a building interior labeled "Parliament chamber illustration" (figure). In the middle there is a cartoon of a ringing bell with the caption "Division bell sounding signals Decision Time" (text) alongside a figure showing a person hurrying toward a chamber labeled "MSP returning to vote" (figure), and a sentence-style label reads "MSPs not in the chamber return to vote" (text). A prominent short time label is included reading "Decisions normally made at 5 pm" (text). Further down a schematic desk console is shown as a simple device figure titled "electronic voting console representation" (figure) with an adjacent explanatory label that reads "members vote using electronic consoles on desks" (text). At the bottom a brief result panel displays the quick outcome with the label "division outcomes known in seconds" (text). The overall style of the image is clean, informational, and infographic-like with clear icons and concise typography.
context: Each sitting day, normally at 5 pm, MSPs decide on all the motions and amendments that have been moved that day. This "Decision Time" is heralded by the sounding of the division bell, which is heard throughout the Parliamentary campus and alerts MSPs who are not in the chamber to return and vote. At Decision Time, the Presiding Officer puts questions on the motions and amendments by reading out the name of the motion or amendment as well as the proposer and asking "Are we all agreed?", to which the chamber first votes orally. If there is audible dissent, the Presiding Officer announces "There will be a division" and members vote by means of electronic consoles on their desks. Each MSP has a unique access card with a microchip which, when inserted into the console, identifies them and allows them to vote. As a result, the outcome of each division is known in seconds.

full_image_caption: The image is an infographic titled "Party Voting Dynamics" (text) focused on "Scottish Parliament voting behavior" (text). At the top there is a bold header followed by a short intro that reads "The outcome of most votes can be predicted beforehand" (text) and a simple cartoon "cartoon of a voting chamber with seated members" (figure) to illustrate the predictable nature of votes, and nearby a label reads "political parties normally instruct members how to vote" (text) to show who gives instructions. In the middle a clear depiction shows a stern "cartoon of an authoritative whip figure holding a clipboard" (figure) accompanied by the concise explanatory caption "whips have the task of ensuring party members vote according to the party line" (text) and another line that states "members are unlikely to reach higher political ranks if they rebel" (text) to convey consequences of defiance. Further down there is a cautionary illustration "cartoon of a ballot box with a crossed-out candidate badge" (figure) paired with the warning text "deselected as official party candidates during future elections" (text) to indicate formal penalties, and a calmer note reads "parties sometimes allow free votes on moral issues" (text) to show exceptions. The overall style of the image is clean, informative infographic with simple cartoons and concise labels.
context: The outcome of most votes can be predicted beforehand since political parties normally instruct members which way to vote. Parties entrust some MSPs, known as whips, with the task of ensuring that party members vote according to the party line. MSPs do not tend to vote against such instructions, since those who do are unlikely to reach higher political ranks in their parties. Errant members can be deselected as official party candidates during future elections, and, in serious cases, may be expelled from their parties outright. Thus, as with many Parliaments, the independence of Members of the Scottish Parliament tends to be low, and backbench rebellions by members who are discontent with their party's policies are rare. In some circumstances, however, parties announce "free votes", which allows Members to vote as they please. This is typically done on moral issues.

context: Immediately after Decision Time a "Members Debate" is held, which lasts for 45 minutes. Members Business is a debate on a motion proposed by an MSP who is not a Scottish minister. Such motions are on issues which may be of interest to a particular area such as a member's own constituency, an upcoming or past event or any other item which would otherwise not be accorded official parliamentary time. As well as the proposer, other members normally contribute to the debate. The relevant minister, whose department the debate and motion relate to "winds up" the debate by speaking after all other participants.

context: Much of the work of the Scottish Parliament is done in committee. The role of committees is stronger in the Scottish Parliament than in other parliamentary systems, partly as a means of strengthening the role of backbenchers in their scrutiny of the government and partly to compensate for the fact that there is no revising chamber. The principal role of committees in the Scottish Parliament is to take evidence from witnesses, conduct inquiries and scrutinise legislation. Committee meetings take place on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday morning when Parliament is sitting. Committees can also meet at other locations throughout Scotland.

context: Committees comprise a small number of MSPs, with membership reflecting the balance of parties across Parliament. There are different committees with their functions set out in different ways. Mandatory Committees are committees which are set down under the Scottish Parliament's standing orders, which govern their remits and proceedings. The current Mandatory Committees in the fourth Session of the Scottish Parliament are: Public Audit; Equal Opportunities; European and External Relations; Finance; Public Petitions; Standards, Procedures and Public Appointments; and Delegated Powers and Law Reform.

context: Subject Committees are established at the beginning of each parliamentary session, and again the members on each committee reflect the balance of parties across Parliament. context: A further type of committee is normally set up to scrutinise private bills submitted to the Scottish Parliament by an outside party or promoter who is not a member of the Scottish Parliament or Scottish Government. full_image_caption: The image is an infographic titled "Scotland Act Overview" (text) focused on "Devolution and Parliamentary Roles" (text). At the top a header shows the main legal reference as "\"The Scotland Act 1998 governs Scottish Parliament functions\" (text)" alongside a small icon of a document represented as "\"Legal document icon\" (figure)". In the middle a block emphasizes royal assent and its source with the quoted caption "\"Queen Elizabeth II gave royal assent on 19 November 1998\" (text)" paired with a symbolic crown illustration shown as "\"Generic crown symbol\" (figure)", and a nearby explanatory line states "\"The Scotland Act 2012 extends devolved competencies\" (text)" while a simple parliament building icon is included as "\"Parliament building symbol\" (figure)". At the bottom the caption clarifies legislative supremacy and accountability with the quoted lines "\"Parliament of the United Kingdom at Westminster is supreme legislature\" (text)" and "\"The Scottish Parliament holds the Scottish Government to account\" (text)". The overall style of the image is clean, informative, and infographic-like with clear icons and concise text.
context: The Scotland Act 1998, which was passed by the Parliament of the United Kingdom and given royal assent by Queen Elizabeth II on 19 November 1998, governs the functions and role of the Scottish Parliament and delimits its legislative competence. The Scotland Act 2012 extends the devolved competencies. For the purposes of parliamentary sovereignty, the Parliament of the United Kingdom at Westminster continues to constitute the supreme legislature of Scotland. However, under the terms of the Scotland Act, Westminster agreed to devolve some of its responsibilities over Scottish domestic policy to the Scottish Parliament. Such "devolved matters" include education, health, agriculture and justice. The Scotland Act enabled the Scottish Parliament to pass primary legislation on these issues. A degree of domestic authority, and all foreign policy, remain with the UK Parliament in Westminster. The Scottish Parliament has the power to pass laws and has limited tax-varying capability. Another of the roles of the Parliament is to hold the Scottish Government to account.

At the top there is a banner showing the captioned icon "Council building" (figure) and a bold label "What counts as a reserved matter listed in Schedule 5" (text), followed by a short explanatory line stating "All matters not specifically reserved are devolved" (text) to clarify why services like police and fire are managed locally. In the middle a pictogram "People discussing policy" (figure) accompanies a cluster of concise policy items displayed as separate tags, including the exact fiscal power phrasing "Ability to alter income tax by up to 3 pence" (text) and an explicit reiteration "Up to 3 pence in the pound" (text) so the precise tax change is clear, and the devolved sectors summarized by the phrase "Agriculture fisheries forestry economic development" (text). Also in the middle a small visual "Traffic sign" (figure) connects to the text tag "Further devolution including setting speed limits" (text) and a label "Powers conferred by the 2012 Act" (text). The overall style of the image is clear, informational, and infographic-like.
context: The specific devolved matters are all subjects which are not explicitly stated in Schedule 5 to the Scotland Act as reserved matters. All matters that are not specifically reserved are automatically devolved to the Scottish Parliament. Most importantly, this includes agriculture, fisheries and forestry, economic development, education, environment, food standards, health, home affairs, Scots law  courts, police and fire services, local government, sport and the arts, transport, training, tourism, research and statistics and social work. The Scottish Parliament has the ability to alter income tax in Scotland by up to 3 pence in the pound. The 2012 Act conferred further fiscal devolution including borrowing powers and some other unconnected matters such as setting speed limits and control of air guns.

context: Reserved matters are subjects that are outside the legislative competence of the Scotland Parliament. The Scottish Parliament is unable to legislate on such issues that are reserved to, and dealt with at, Westminster (and where Ministerial functions usually lie with UK Government ministers). These include abortion, broadcasting policy, civil service, common markets for UK goods and services, constitution, electricity, coal, oil, gas, nuclear energy, defence and national security, drug policy, employment, foreign policy and relations with Europe, most aspects of transport safety and regulation, National Lottery, protection of borders, social security and stability of UK's fiscal, economic and monetary system.

context: Stage 1 is the first, or introductory stage of the bill, where the minister or member in charge of the bill will formally introduce it to Parliament together with its accompanying documents  Explanatory Notes, a Policy Memorandum setting out the policy underlying the bill, and a Financial Memorandum setting out the costs and savings associated with it. Statements from the Presiding Officer and the member in charge of the bill are also lodged indicating whether the bill is within the legislative competence of the Parliament. Stage 1 usually takes place, initially, in the relevant committee or committees and is then submitted to the whole Parliament for a full debate in the chamber on the general principles of the bill. If the whole Parliament agrees in a vote to the general principles of the bill, it then proceeds to Stage 2.

context: Stage 3 is the final stage of the bill and is considered at a meeting of the whole Parliament. This stage comprises two parts: consideration of amendments to the bill as a general debate, and a final vote on the bill. Opposition members can table "wrecking amendments" to the bill, designed to thwart further progress and take up parliamentary time, to cause the bill to fall without a final vote being taken. After a general debate on the final form of the bill, members proceed to vote at Decision Time on whether they agree to the general principles of the final bill.

context: Royal assent: After the bill has been passed, the Presiding Officer submits it to the Monarch for royal assent and it becomes an Act of the Scottish Parliament. However he cannot do so until a 4-week period has elapsed, during which the Law Officers of the Scottish Government or UK Government can refer the bill to the Supreme Court of the United Kingdom for a ruling on whether it is within the powers of the Parliament. Acts of the Scottish Parliament do not begin with a conventional enacting formula. Instead they begin with a phrase that reads: "The Bill for this Act of the Scottish Parliament was passed by the Parliament on [Date] and received royal assent on [Date]".

full_image_caption: The image is an infographic titled "Scottish Government Formation" (text) focused on "How the Scottish Government is formed" (text). At the top there is a clear banner reading "The party, or parties, that hold the majority of seats in the Parliament forms the Scottish Government" (text) and an icon showing a stylized government building labeled "government building" (figure), and to introduce the process a caption reads "Parliament elects a First Minister from candidates at each term" (text) with a simple cartoon of a voting ballot and ballot box captioned "voting ballot" (figure). In the middle a callout states "Any member can put their name forward to be First Minister" (text) alongside a figure of a raised hand labeled "raised hand" (figure), and another panel explains "Most ministers and their juniors are drawn from amongst the elected MSPs" (text). Toward the bottom a legal note reads "The First Minister chooses ministers but formal appointment or dismissal is made by the Sovereign" (text) and a final caption reiterates "First Minister is elected at the beginning of each parliamentary term" (text). The overall style of the image is clean, informative, and infographic-like.
context: The party, or parties, that hold the majority of seats in the Parliament forms the Scottish Government. In contrast to many other parliamentary systems, Parliament elects a First Minister from a number of candidates at the beginning of each parliamentary term (after a general election). Any member can put their name forward to be First Minister, and a vote is taken by all members of Parliament. Normally, the leader of the largest party is returned as First Minister, and head of the Scottish Government. Theoretically, Parliament also elects the Scottish Ministers who form the government of Scotland and sit in the Scottish cabinet, but such ministers are, in practice, appointed to their roles by the First Minister. Junior ministers, who do not attend cabinet, are also appointed to assist Scottish ministers in their departments. Most ministers and their juniors are drawn from amongst the elected MSPs, with the exception of Scotland's Chief Law Officers: the Lord Advocate and the Solicitor General. Whilst the First Minister chooses the ministers  and may decide to remove them at any time  the formal appointment or dismissal is made by the Sovereign.

full_image_caption: The image is an infographic titled "Scottish Parliament Election Timing" (text) focused on "Ordinary and Extraordinary Election Rules" (text). At the top there is a clear header reading "Ordinary elections every four years on first Thursday in May" (text) alongside a simple symbolic graphic of a calendar with a circled day captioned "\"Generic informational graphic\" (figure)"; in the middle a line of explanatory text states "Monarch may vary the date by up to one month" (text) paired with a small symbolic crown icon captioned "\"Simple symbolic crown\" (figure)" to show who can change the date on the Presiding Officers proposal, and an adjacent concise rule block reads "Parliament has twenty eight days to choose the First Minister" (text) with a cartoon document graphic captioned "\"Stylized policy document\" (figure) indicating the 28day nomination requirement; at the bottom a final guidance line reads "Extraordinary elections supplant ordinary elections if held within six months" (text) and another note reads "Ordinary election schedule reverts to first Thursday in May" (text). The overall style of the image is clean, infographicstyle, with clear icons and legible instructional typography.
context: Under the Scotland Act 1998, ordinary general elections for the Scottish Parliament are held on the first Thursday in May every four years (1999, 2003, 2007 and so on). The date of the poll may be varied by up to one month either way by the Monarch on the proposal of the Presiding Officer. If the Parliament itself resolves that it should be dissolved (with at least two-thirds of the Members voting in favour), or if the Parliament fails to nominate one of its members to be First Minister within 28 days of a General Election or of the position becoming vacant, the Presiding Officer proposes a date for an extraordinary general election and the Parliament is dissolved by the Queen by royal proclamation. Extraordinary general elections are in addition to ordinary general elections, unless held less than six months before the due date of an ordinary general election, in which case they supplant it. The following ordinary election reverts to the first Thursday in May, a multiple of four years after 1999 (i.e., 5 May 2011, 7 May 2015, etc.).

context: Several procedures enable the Scottish Parliament to scrutinise the Government. The First Minister or members of the cabinet can deliver statements to Parliament upon which MSPs are invited to question. For example, at the beginning of each parliamentary year, the First Minister delivers a statement to the chamber setting out the Government's legislative programme for the forthcoming year. After the statement has been delivered, the leaders of the opposition parties and other MSPs question the First Minister on issues related to the substance of the statement.

context: Parliamentary time is also set aside for question periods in the debating chamber. A "General Question Time" takes place on a Thursday between 11:40 a.m. and 12 p.m. where members can direct questions to any member of the Scottish Government. At 2.30pm, a 40-minute long themed "Question Time" takes place, where members can ask questions of ministers in departments that are selected for questioning that sitting day, such as health and justice or education and transport. Between 12 p.m. and 12:30 p.m. on Thursdays, when Parliament is sitting, First Minister's Question Time takes place. This gives members an opportunity to question the First Minister directly on issues under their jurisdiction. Opposition leaders ask a general question of the First Minister and then supplementary questions. Such a practice enables a "lead-in" to the questioner, who then uses their supplementary question to ask the First Minister any issue. The four general questions available to opposition leaders are:

context: Of the 129 MSPs, 73 are elected to represent first past the post constituencies and are known as "Constituency MSPs". Voters choose one member to represent the constituency, and the member with most votes is returned as a constituency MSP. The 73 Scottish Parliament constituencies shared the same boundaries as the UK Parliament constituencies in Scotland, prior to the 2005 reduction in the number of Scottish MPs, with the exception of Orkney and Shetland which each return their own constituency MSP. Currently, the average Scottish Parliament constituency comprises 55,000 electors. Given the geographical distribution of population in Scotland, this results in constituencies of a smaller area in the Central Lowlands, where the bulk of Scotland's population live, and much larger constituency areas in the north and west of the country, which have a low population density. The island archipelagos of Orkney, Shetland and the Western Isles comprise a much smaller number of electors, due to their dispersed population and distance from the Scottish Parliament in Edinburgh. If a Constituency MSP resigns from Parliament, this triggers a by-election in his or her constituency, where a replacement MSP is returned from one of the parties by the plurality system.

Integrated into the middle narrative is an explicit reiteration reading "Proportionally to the number of votes received" (text) to mirror the allocation principle, and there is a repeating loop graphic labeled "Process repeated iteratively until all list seats allocated" (figure) paired with a caption reading "Allocation proceeds iteratively until all seats are filled" (text). context: The total number of seats in the Parliament are allocated to parties proportionally to the number of votes received in the second vote of the ballot using the d'Hondt method. For example, to determine who is awarded the first list seat, the number of list votes cast for each party is divided by one plus the number of seats the party won in the region (at this point just constituency seats). The party with the highest quotient is awarded the seat, which is then added to its constituency seats in allocating the second seat. This is repeated iteratively until all available list seats are allocated.

context: As in the House of Commons, a number of qualifications apply to being an MSP. Such qualifications were introduced under the House of Commons Disqualification Act 1975 and the British Nationality Act 1981. Specifically, members must be over the age of 18 and must be a citizen of the United Kingdom, the Republic of Ireland, one of the countries in the Commonwealth of Nations, a citizen of a British overseas territory, or a European Union citizen resident in the UK. Members of the police and the armed forces are disqualified from sitting in the Scottish Parliament as elected MSPs, and similarly, civil servants and members of foreign legislatures are disqualified. An individual may not sit in the Scottish Parliament if he or she is judged to be insane under the terms of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment) (Scotland) Act 2003.

context: The election produced a majority SNP government, making this the first time in the Scottish Parliament where a party has commanded a parliamentary majority. The SNP took 16 seats from Labour, with many of their key figures not returned to parliament, although Labour leader Iain Gray retained East Lothian by 151 votes. The SNP took a further eight seats from the Liberal Democrats and one seat from the Conservatives. The SNP overall majority meant that there was sufficient support in the Scottish Parliament to hold a referendum on Scottish independence.

context: For the Conservatives, the main disappointment was the loss of Edinburgh Pentlands, the seat of former party leader David McLetchie, to the SNP. McLetchie was elected on the Lothian regional list and the Conservatives suffered a net loss of five seats, with leader Annabel Goldie claiming that their support had held firm. Nevertheless, she too announced she would step down as leader of the party. Cameron congratulated the SNP on their victory but vowed to campaign for the Union in the independence referendum.

At the top there is a clear header reading "the West Lothian question" (text) and a small symbolic illustration showing a generic lawbook being split into parts labelled "devolved" and "reserved" as a visual, "Split lawbook" (figure); in the middle a panel states "able to vote on domestic legislation that applies only to England, Wales and Northern Ireland" (text) accompanied by a simple cartoon of three linked parliament benches to symbolize cross-constituency voting, "Linked benches" (figure), and an adjacent concise tag explains this as a "procedural consequence of Scottish Parliament creation" (text) to directly state the procedural outcome. Below this a contrasting panel reads "domestic legislation of the Scottish Parliament" (text) paired with a single isolated parliament bench icon to show restriction, "Isolated bench" (figure). Further down a note references "the Conservative victory in the 2015 UK election" (text) alongside a small parliamentary gavel symbol to indicate procedural change, and another short caption states "MPs representing English constituencies can veto laws affecting England" (text) to show the resulting rule change. The overall style of the image is clear, instructional, and infographic-like with clean icons and concise explanatory text.
context: A procedural consequence of the establishment of the Scottish Parliament is that Scottish MPs sitting in the UK House of Commons are able to vote on domestic legislation that applies only to England, Wales and Northern Ireland  whilst English, Scottish, Welsh and Northern Irish Westminster MPs are unable to vote on the domestic legislation of the Scottish Parliament. This phenomenon is known as the West Lothian question and has led to criticism. Following the Conservative victory in the 2015 UK election, standing orders of the House of Commons were changed to give MPs representing English constituencies a new "veto" over laws only affecting England.

At the top there is a clear headline presented as "\"Islamism Overview\" (text)" and an introductory subtitle shown as "\"Political Islam and Societal Change\" (text)", followed by a concise definition displayed as "\"Islamism is an Islamic revival movement characterized by moral conservatism\" (text)" and a supporting line shown as "\"It seeks to implement Islamic values in all spheres of life\" (text) which explains the movements aim. In the middle a symbolic icon is provided as "\"Government and society reordering icon\" (figure)" to represent the goal to "\"reorder government and society in accordance with the Shari'a\" (text)", and alongside it a contrasting symbolic graphic appears as "\"Two-pole balance illustration\" (figure)" to depict how movements oscillate between poles, with a nearby explanatory line reading "\"Movements oscillate between revolutionary and reformist strategies\" (text) and another text panel stating "\"One strategy is seizure of state power by revolution or invasion\" (text) to show the more forceful approach. At the bottom a final supportive symbol is shown as "\"Grassroots reform visual\" (figure)" illustrating the reformist, gradual Islamization from the bottom up, and a concluding note reads "\"Movements have redefined politics and borders in the Middle East\" (text). The overall style of the image is clean, informative, and infographic-friendly.
context: Islamism, also known as Political Islam (Arabic:   islm siys), is an Islamic revival movement often characterized by moral conservatism, literalism, and the attempt "to implement Islamic values in all spheres of life." Islamism favors the reordering of government and society in accordance with the Shari'a. The different Islamist movements have been described as "oscillating between two poles": at one end is a strategy of Islamization of society through state power seized by revolution or invasion; at the other "reformist" pole Islamists work to Islamize society gradually "from the bottom up". The movements have "arguably altered the Middle East more than any trend since the modern states gained independence", redefining "politics and even borders" according to one journalist (Robin Wright).

context: Moderate and reformist Islamists who accept and work within the democratic process include parties like the Tunisian Ennahda Movement. Jamaat-e-Islami of Pakistan is basically a socio-political and democratic Vanguard party but has also gained political influence through military coup d'tat in past. The Islamist groups like Hezbollah in Lebanon and Hamas in Palestine participate in democratic and political process as well as armed attacks, seeking to abolish the state of Israel. Radical Islamist organizations like al-Qaeda and the Egyptian Islamic Jihad, and groups such as the Taliban, entirely reject democracy, often declaring as kuffar those Muslims who support it (see takfirism), as well as calling for violent/offensive jihad or urging and conducting attacks on a religious basis.

full_image_caption: The image is an infographic titled "Divisions and Dynamics in Islamism" (text) focused on "Islamism, Salafis, Muslim Brotherhood, and democracy" (text). At the top a bold heading is supported by a simple emblem: "Islamist movements and their divisions" (text), and an icon suggests overview with a generic map-like shape: "Overview symbol" (figure). Moving into the middle the graphic juxtaposes two labeled strands using short explanatory captions, one labeled "major division between fundamentalist and reformist Islamism" (text) with a symbolic guardian figure: "Abstract guardian figure" (figure), and the other labeled "Muslim Brotherhood as vanguard of Islamic reform" (text) with a stylized reformer silhouette: "Abstract reformer figure" (figure). A nearby callout explains historical change with the line "Sunni pan-Islamism underwent a remarkable shift" (text) and another succinct note states "Salafi emphasis on sharia rather than institutions" (text). At the bottom a concluding section links political dynamics with democracy showing a ballot-box icon: "Voting ballot symbol" (figure) alongside the caption "Islamism increasingly interdependent with democracy" (text) and the explanatory line "Islamists need democratic elections to maintain their legitimacy" (text). The overall style of the image is clean, explanatory, and infographic-like with clear icons and concise text.
context: Another major division within Islamism is between what Graham E. Fuller has described as the fundamentalist "guardians of the tradition" (Salafis, such as those in the Wahhabi movement) and the "vanguard of change and Islamic reform" centered around the Muslim Brotherhood. Olivier Roy argues that "Sunni pan-Islamism underwent a remarkable shift in the second half of the 20th century" when the Muslim Brotherhood movement and its focus on Islamisation of pan-Arabism was eclipsed by the Salafi movement with its emphasis on "sharia rather than the building of Islamic institutions," and rejection of Shia Islam. Following the Arab Spring, Roy has described Islamism as "increasingly interdependent" with democracy in much of the Arab Muslim world, such that "neither can now survive without the other." While Islamist political culture itself may not be democratic, Islamists need democratic elections to maintain their legitimacy. At the same time, their popularity is such that no government can call itself democratic that excludes mainstream Islamist groups.

full_image_caption: The image is an infographic titled "Islamism and Political Islam" (text) focused on "debate over Islamism's political role" (text). At the top there is a compact header with the phrase "Islamism seeks a political role for Islam" (text) accompanied by a simple symbolic mosque-and-capitol hybrid icon labeled "institutional concept" (figure), and just below that a short explanatory line reads "supporters believe their views reflect Islam" (text) while a contrasting portrait-bust cartoon labeled "academic observer" (figure) represents critics who disagree. In the middle a boxed quote reads "Scholars and observers reject Islam as mere political ideology" (text) and a schematic balance scale cartoon (figure) visually contrasts "illiberal Islamic regimes" (text) on one side with a small civic protest icon labeled "progressive moderates" (figure) on the other, and a connecting caption states "failure to distinguish Islam from Islamism leads many in the West to support illiberal Islamic regimes" (text). context: Islamism is a controversial concept not just because it posits a political role for Islam but also because its supporters believe their views merely reflect Islam, while the contrary idea that Islam is, or can be, apolitical is an error. Scholars and observers who do not believe that Islam is merely a political ideology include Fred Halliday, John Esposito and Muslim intellectuals like Javed Ahmad Ghamidi. Hayri Abaza argues the failure to distinguish between Islam and Islamism leads many in the West to support illiberal Islamic regimes, to the detriment of progressive moderates who seek to separate religion from politics.

context: Egyptian President Anwar Sadat  whose policies included opening Egypt to Western investment (infitah); transferring Egypt's allegiance from the Soviet Union to the United States; and making peace with Israel  released Islamists from prison and welcomed home exiles in tacit exchange for political support in his struggle against leftists. His "encouraging of the emergence of the Islamist movement" was said to have been "imitated by many other Muslim leaders in the years that followed."  This "gentlemen's agreement" between Sadat and Islamists broke down in 1975 but not before Islamists came to completely dominate university student unions. Sadat was later assassinated and a formidable insurgency was formed in Egypt in the 1990s. The French government has also been reported to have promoted Islamist preachers "in the hope of channeling Muslim energies into zones of piety and charity."

context: The interpretation of Islam promoted by this funding was the strict, conservative Saudi-based Wahhabism or Salafism. In its harshest form it preached that Muslims should not only "always oppose" infidels "in every way," but "hate them for their religion ... for Allah's sake," that democracy "is responsible for all the horrible wars of the 20th century," that Shia and other non-Wahhabi Muslims were infidels, etc. While this effort has by no means converted all, or even most Muslims to the Wahhabist interpretation of Islam, it has done much to overwhelm more moderate local interpretations, and has set the Saudi-interpretation of Islam as the "gold standard" of religion in minds of some or many Muslims.

At the top there is a header with the phrase "While studying law and philosophy in England and Germany" (text) and a small portrait represented by "Generic portrait of a scholarly figure" (figure), so viewers immediately see his educational background and connection to Europe; in the middle a labeled banner reads "Member of the All India Muslim League in London" (text) alongside a symbolic icon "Generic group of people symbol" (figure) that conveys his political affiliation, and a captioned date block says "Returned to Lahore in 1908 after studies" (text) while another clear text block reads "mainstream Indian nationalist and secularist Indian National Congress" (text) to explicitly state who he criticized and directly answer the QA entry; below that a stylized book image labeled "Generic closed book with pages" (figure) is paired with the phrase "The Reconstruction of Religious Thought in Islam published 1934" (text) indicating the title and publication year of his English lectures, and a small question-note graphic "Generic question mark document" (figure) with the phrase "No evidence for study in Ireland or joining organizations in France" (text) to reflect unanswered items in the QA list. context: While studying law and philosophy in England and Germany, Iqbal became a member of the London branch of the All India Muslim League. He came back to Lahore in 1908. While dividing his time between law practice and philosophical poetry, Iqbal had remained active in the Muslim League. He did not support Indian involvement in World War I and remained in close touch with Muslim political leaders such as Muhammad Ali Johar and Muhammad Ali Jinnah. He was a critic of the mainstream Indian nationalist and secularist Indian National Congress. Iqbal's seven English lectures were published by Oxford University press in 1934 in a book titled The Reconstruction of Religious Thought in Islam. These lectures dwell on the role of Islam as a religion as well as a political and legal philosophy in the modern age.

full_image_caption: The image is an infographic titled "Iqbal's Political Vision" (text) focused on "Iqbal's concerns and legacy" (text). At the top there is a header and a small emblem, and a clear quoted statement "Iqbal feared secularism and secular nationalism" (text) introduces his worry about forces that would weaken Islamic spiritual foundations while a simple symbolic globe is shown as "\"Symbolic globe representing ideological forces\" (figure)"; in the middle a quoted line "India's mostly Hindu population would crowd out Muslim heritage" (text) is paired with a cartoon of two overlapping cultural monuments depicted as "\"Two monuments illustrating cultural tension\" (figure)" to show the crowding out concern, and another quoted note "called for shedding nationalist differences for unity" (text) explains his call to end divisive politics while a third small figure shows "\"Group of people symbolizing political unity\" (figure)"; at the bottom a compact timeline contains the quoted phrase "elected president of the Muslim League in 1930" (text) alongside a final emphasized caption "his Allahabad address inspired the Pakistan movement" (text) to link the address to later outcomes. The overall style of the image is clean, informative, and infographic-like with clear icons and concise typography.
context: Iqbal expressed fears that not only would secularism and secular nationalism weaken the spiritual foundations of Islam and Muslim society, but that India's Hindu-majority population would crowd out Muslim heritage, culture and political influence. In his travels to Egypt, Afghanistan, Palestine and Syria, he promoted ideas of greater Islamic political co-operation and unity, calling for the shedding of nationalist differences. Sir Muhammad Iqbal was elected president of the Muslim League in 1930 at its session in Allahabad as well as for the session in Lahore in 1932. In his Allahabad Address on 29 December 1930, Iqbal outlined a vision of an independent state for Muslim-majority provinces in northwestern India. This address later inspired the Pakistan movement.

At the top there is a bold header next to a portrait illustration labeled "portrait of founder figure" (figure) and a short strapline reading "Sayyid Abul Ala Maududi was an important early twentieth-century figure" (text), and below that a caption-style line stating "Trained as a lawyer but chose journalism as his profession" (text). In the middle a timeline band carries a simple symbolic calendar icon "timeline milestone symbol" (figure) with an adjacent concise label "Founded the Jamaat-e-Islami party in 1941" (text) and a stack-of-books graphic "stack of generic books" (figure) accompanied by the sentence-like text "He had most impact through his writing" (text). The overall style of the image is clean, informational, and documentary.
context: Sayyid Abul Ala Maududi was an important early twentieth-century figure in the Islamic revival in India, and then after independence from Britain, in Pakistan. Trained as a lawyer he chose the profession of journalism, and wrote about contemporary issues and most importantly about Islam and Islamic law. Maududi founded the Jamaat-e-Islami party in 1941 and remained its leader until 1972. However, Maududi had much more impact through his writing than through his political organising. His extremely influential books (translated into many languages) placed Islam in a modern context, and influenced not only conservative ulema but liberal modernizer Islamists such as al-Faruqi, whose "Islamization of Knowledge" carried forward some of Maududi's key principles.

full_image_caption: The image is an infographic titled "Maududis Vision" (text) focused on "Islamic State and Revolution" (text). At the top there is a clear header reading "Maududis Vision" (text) alongside a simple symbolic graphic of a person speaking to a crowd rendered as a generic silhouette scene, "\"Speaker and audience\" (figure)". In the middle the infographic presents three connected concept boxes that read "Sharia required for Islamic society" (text), "an Islamic state must be established" (text) and "unity of God (tawhid) explained" (text), while an illustrative icon of a book and scales conveys law and scripture, "\"Book and scales\" (figure)". At the bottom a summarizing caption reads "gradual Islamic revolution through hearts and minds" (text). The overall style of the image is clean, didactic, infographic-like with simple icons and legible sans-serif text.
context: Maududi also believed that Muslim society could not be Islamic without Sharia, and Islam required the establishment of an Islamic state. This state should be a "theo-democracy," based on the principles of: tawhid (unity of God), risala (prophethood) and khilafa (caliphate). Although Maududi talked about Islamic revolution, by "revolution" he meant not the violence or populist policies of the Iranian Revolution, but the gradual changing the hearts and minds of individuals from the top of society downward through an educational process or da'wah.
